description: Antonine Primary School’s P5 class planted two wee Bee Beds in their school grounds and learnt about the ecological importance of pollination and its connection with food security. They also learnt about the lifecycle of red mason bees and received a solitary bee observation nest box to observe the nesting activity of a range of species
what_was_planted:
Cultivated Perennials
Agastache 'Blackadder'
Anchusa azurea 'Loddon Royalist'
Anthemis tinctoria 'Sauce Hollandaise'
Armeria maritima
Catananche caerulea 'Major'
Centaurea macrocephala
Centranthus ruber var. coccineus
Cephalaria gigantea
Cirsium rivulare 'Atropurpureum'
Erigeron karvinskianus
Knautia macedonica
Lavandula angustifolia 'Hidcote'
Origanum vulgare
Perovskia 'Blue Spire'
Phlomis ruselliana
Potentilla atrosanguinea
Salvia nemorosa ‘Cardonna’
Stachys byzantina 'Silver Carpet'

Cultivated Annuals
Antirrhinum (mixed)
Bidens ferrufolia ‘Golden Glory’
Cerinthe major ‘Purpurascens’
Cosmos ‘White Purity’
Dahlia ‘Bishop of Llandaff’
Echium ‘Blue Bedder ‘

description: St Joseph’s Primary School planted a Bee Bed in a secluded spot in their grounds. The children learnt about the importance of having a variety of flowers and a long flowering season to support a wide range of pollinators. They also learnt about the lifecycle of red mason bees and received a solitary bee observation nest box to observe the nesting activity of a range of species

The GalGael Trust is an Ibrox-based ‘working community making a stand for compassion, health and justice, standing against violence’.

description: The Centre Livingston have established four very large Bee Beds as part of an initiative to improve their expansive grounds for biodiversity. Two are positioned in bright, sunny spots and the other two are situated on a shady verge. The beds provide an uplifting focal point for staff and visitors to the shopping centre. We hope more such establishments will make similar efforts to boost biodiversity! Steering formal planting towards perennial and wildlife-friendly is an excellent step!

description: RePollinate worked with HP Inc to reduce the longterm maintenance of two established courtyard gardens at the Stobhill Hospital through selectively removing problem plants. Additional plants with high value to pollinators were brought in to plug gaps left in the garden beds, as well as plant six raised beds. The plants will greatly extend the flowering season of the gardens

Cultivated Perennials
Epimedium x warleyense 'Orangekonigin'
Geranium himalayense 'Baby Blue'

Verbena hastata 'Alba'

description: RePollinate worked with HP Inc to reimagine a large flower bed in a rooftop courtyard garden of a children’s ward at QEUH. Ornamental shrubs were selectively pulled out and replaced with a sensory, prairie-style planting, including plants with diverse textures, smells and structures. The enclosed, rooftop nature of the space is ideal for low maintenance gardening as unwanted plants coming in as seed are a rarer occurrence
what_was_planted:
Cultivated Perennials
Achnatherum calamagrostis 
Briza media 'Tinkerbell' 
Calamintha nepeta 'Blue Cloud' 
Cirsium rivulare 'Atropurpureum' 
Eryngium planum 'Blaukappe'

Geranium macr. 'Ingwersen's Var.'

description: RePollinate worked with HP Inc to brighten up an entrance to the Oral Health ward at the Royal Alexandra Hospital. The area  is very shady and needed brightening, so two bespoke, wooden planters were constructed by a local carpenter and positioned beside the doorway. A diverse array of perennials were planted, all highly shade tolerant, and together providing an extended period of flowering with evergreen leaves for winter interest
what_was_planted:
Cultivated Perennials
Galium odoratum
Geranium macr. 'Ingwersen's Var.'
Geum 'Totally Tangerine’
Helleborus x hyb. 'White Lady'
Lamium orvala Album
Persicaria amplex. 'Orange Field'
Pulmonaria 'Ice Ballet'
Viola odorata 'Königin Charlotte'

description: Working with Falkirk Council, RePollinate re-established two large rose beds at the perimeter of this community rose garden. A variety of ornamental roses were used planted as replacements for those that had died, and further planting of pollinator friendly shrubs, herbaceous perennials and bulbs provide longer lasting colour, as well as habitat and forage for wildlife
what_was_planted:
Shrubs
Lavandula angustifolia 'Hidcote' 
Lavandula x Intermedia ‘Gros Bleu’
Potentilla fruticosa (4 colours)
Roses (Floribunda)

Cultivated Perennials

description: Working with Falkirk Council, the Friends of Dollar Park and the Cyrenians planted three Bee Beds in the Park, including a former fountain and two nearby ground-level beds. The beds were designed as a hybrid between cottage garden and North American prairie, with a mixture of European and North American varieties, as well as ornamental grasses. Drought-tolerant plants were also selected for the fountain to cascade over its sides at height

description: With Falkirk Council and Cllr Robert Bisset as lead, children from several local primary schools assisted in enhancing two ornamental shrubberies at the War Memorial. The schools were asked what style of planting they would like and they opted for naturalistic/wild, so lots of native and near-native shrubs and herbaceous perennials were selected to diversify the existing potentilla shrubs. It’s really forward thinking of the community to plants with nature in mind in such a formal setting. Why not!

description: In partnership with Falkirk Council, Zetland Park Bowling Club opted for a very low growing planting in a long bed at the foot of the bowling green from the clubhouse. description: Ibrox and Cessnock Community Council planted two Bee Beds in a shady spot along a lane that runs adjacent to the back gardens of residences along Walmer Crescent in Cessnock. One of the beds lies beneath a mature ash tree, meaning that there is significant disparity in the wetness of the soil between the two beds. Plants were carefully selected to accommodate this. It is hoped that the plantings will encourage further such schemes along this lane and others!

description: Fortune Works Enable Glasgow empower people with learning disabilities to get the most from life. The team incorporated deadwood and a small pond in their Bee Bed. A very unique touch which we really liked! The heavy clay soil meant that plants needed to be very tolerant of waterlogging, so in the pond theme, plants were selected that you might see beside a small water body.

description: The gardening team at St Paul’s Youth Forum - a brilliant youth centre with a bicycle hub -planted a long bed at the front of their base. The bed is east-facing, so required relatively shade-tolerant plants. Most shade-loving plants flower early, but the use of varieties such as sneezewort, Dalmatian bellflower, common toadflax and Japanese anemone means that the Bee Bed also benefits from some late flowering
